DISCUSS: DISCUSSION DISCUSS: The purpose of this narrative systematic review was to synthesize and appraise evidence on Canadian school food and nutrition interventions, programs, and policies, and their impact on diets and nutritional status among school-aged children and adolescents. We assessed primary studies within the peer-reviewed and grey literature to provide a holistic picture of current school food environments in local, provincial, and multiregional settings. To contextualize results within the broader food systems concept, we discuss the evidence as it relates to the political, social, and physical environments, as well as the impact on individual food choice, dietary behaviors, and nutritional status. We also provide 5 key recommendations (Panel 1) based on the summary of findings. TABLE: Recommendations to Improve School Food and Nutrition in Canada TABLE: 1. Improve interdisciplinary collaboration between the health and education sectors to design, implement, monitor, and evaluate existing and new interventions and programs to ensure they meet current nutritional guidelines and produce intended nutritional outcomes among youth. This should include collaboration within and between provincial ministries in order to develop comprehensive and standardized indicators to ensure provincial guidelines can be monitored routinely and evaluated comparably.	 	2. Consider the multifactorial context that influences the nutrition and health lifestyle choices and practices in children and adolescents, including systemic, institutional, parental and family, societal and peer influences, and individual choice.	 	3. Greater community and stakeholder engagement for better design and infrastructure of policies and programs, especially amongst programming for Indigenous populations given current evidence indicates sustainability and success is associated with community involvement. This will include the participation of parents and guardians, students, teachers and administration, and other key stakeholders to ensure future programming is tailored appropriately to the populations they aim to serve.	 	4. Prioritize the use of alternative methods and the assessment of different outcomes, such as behavior change, anthropometric and micronutrient outcomes, to evaluate program effectiveness. Program evaluation should also consider longitudinal evaluations to monitor the long-term effects, impact, and sustainability of these interventions.	 	5. Future research should examine how the implementation of universal school food and nutrition programs and policies can ultimately ensure healthy diets for those that are predominantly affected by food insecurity and other food system inequities. This includes Indigenous populations, especially situated in the Territories, and other ethnically diverse communities, communities with predominantly low socioeconomic status, and metropolitan regions with large food deserts. DISCUSS: Political environment DISCUSS: Although the federal government recently announced its plan for a national school food policy, to date, there is still no school food or nutrition mandate that exists at the federal level, with the exception of Canadaâs food guide. It is also no secret that Canada lags far behind other high-income countries as one of the only Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries lacking a national school food program and policy. In a recent study by Hock et al, youths 10â17âyears old from Australia, Canada, Chile, Mexico, the United Kingdom, and the United States participated in the International Food Policy Study Youth Survey, which found countries with the most comprehensive national school meal policies (Chile and the United States) had the greatest meal and nutrition coverage across their student populations. This is compared with less-comprehensive national policies in the United Kingdom and Mexico, and no policies in Australia and Canada (only 5% of Canadian students participated in a school meal program). The study also showed that Canada especially fell short among its most vulnerable populations. Hock et al also reported that only 27% of students with the most food insecurity participated in some form of a school meal program, whereas in Chile and the United States, more than two-thirds of their vulnerable student populations accessed a school meal. This highlights the importance and strong influence of national-level food policies on student nutrition and health, which Canada has yet to implement. DISCUSS: In addition to school meal programs, national legislation is also required to address inappropriate marketing of unhealthy products, particularly those targeted at youth, alongside policies that dictate the provision of nutritious and sustainable meals in schools. A 2020 report by the World Health Organization, UNICEF, and Lancet Commission, Children in All Policies 2030, called for a new global initiative to put the health and well-being of children and adolescents at the center of global and national efforts to achieve sustainable development. Of relevance is 1 of the primary objectives of this initiative to protect children of all ages from the harmful impacts of food marketing, which is also reflected in the World Health Organization Set of Recommendations on the Marketing of Foods and Non-Alcoholic Beverages to Children and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Governments have been repeatedly called upon to restrict unhealthy food and beverage marketing to children and adolescents because this marketing exploits their health and development. However, the only âguidelinesâ in Canada were implemented in 2007 (by the Canadian Childrenâs Food and Beverage Advertising Initiative) and stipulated voluntary self-regulation of marketing practices by the food industry. The lack of legislation is largely due to industry stakeholders interacting with the government, such as the recent lobbying against a proposed bill in 2018 (Bill S-228). This is in exception to Quebecâs Consumer Protection Act (1980), which was the first legislation that does not permit commercial marketing to children younger than 13âyears on all marketing media and channels. DISCUSS: Despite no federal-level legislation addressing harmful marketing practices, there is clear acknowledgement of the need to improve affordability, accessibility, and advertisement of healthy foods and beverages. Marketing of branded and/or unhealthy food and beverage items, such as chocolate, pizza, and other fast foods, remains pervasive across the country. Adherence to marketing guidelines and policies implemented at the local level is also an area of concern. A study in British Columbia showed that 26% of promotions violated the Board of Educationâs advertising policies and only 13% displayed appropriate nutritional messaging. This evidence further raises the issues of regulation, adherence, and compliance when there is absence of official governmental legislation. Although the Association of Canadian Advertisers, the Canadian Beverage Association and Food, Health & Consumer Products of Canada, and Restaurants Canada recently created the âFood and Beverage Advertising Codeâ to outline marketing conditions that advertisements catered to children are expected to comply with by summer 2023, this, too, is not legislation, and regulation remains unclear. DISCUSS: The lack of federal and provincial (save Quebec) guidance and leadership has placed an onus on school boards, local governance, and other organizations to develop and implement their own policies for in-school advertising and programming and ensure these align with international guidelines. However, the effectiveness and compliance of these local actions are questionable. Our review found that school meal programs were offered at random and based on voluntary local or provincial implementation with no cohesive strategy or standards even within the same province. This is also reflected in the adoption of the HPS approach or its equivalent in Alberta, British Columbia, Ontario, and Nova Scotia. These programs were interpreted and contextualized based on each province to encourage enabling school food environments (eg, APPLE Schools, Healthy Buddies, AS! BC, ANHPSP, Battle River Project, Health Promoting Secondary Schools). To further demonstrate this sheer complexity, in Nova Scotia alone, a smaller province within the country, there were 70 provincial policies and 509 policies across 8 public school regions that were relevant to the HPS framework. This review illustrates that there are numerous policies and programs, with varying designs, implementation strategies, and mixed results in terms of their effectiveness on improved behaviors, diets, or nutrition, making meaningful comparison between programs or policies, and provinces and territories extremely challenging. Likewise, a multiregional survey using a representative sample of high school students from 7 provinces (nâ=â12â110) found that neither healthful nor nonhealthful eating behaviors differed significantly between schools with voluntary (OR, 0.83; 95%CI, 0.64, 1.08) and mandatory (OR, 1.16; 95%CI, 0.83, 1.64) nutrition policies. DISCUSS: Ultimately, there is a patchwork of provincial and local actions that has developed over the years that govern and influence the Canadian school food environment. Given the vastness of the country and the diversity of populations, settings, and governance structures, schools have implemented a wide range of food environment and nutrition policies according to their individual missions and student needs, including direct provision, safeguards against marketing branded or highly processed foods and beverages, school meal standards, and nutrition education. DISCUSS: Physical environment DISCUSS: In addition to political factors, a key area of change and beneficial impact in the school food environment is improving the physical space through food availability and accessibility, and the physical infrastructure and capacity of schools to provide food and beverages. Across Canada, 7 provincial guidelines have been released on the nutritional profile of foods and beverages provided in schools, with many being updated since the release of the 2019 food guidelines for Canada. Although a recent and comprehensive school food environment assessment has yet to be conducted across Canada, Browning et al surveyed 436 primary and secondary schools in 2013 to understand food access within and around schools, as well as availability of healthy food options. Their findings suggest that although schools had access to a cafeteria, shop, or vending machine, the provision of healthy options was greatest in cafeterias (89.3% of schools) and lowest in vending machines (41.3%), and only 39.9% of schools had access to fruits and vegetables. DISCUSS: Assessing food availability and accessibility beyond the supply and distribution of food to schools remains an important consideration, given school-based nutrition interventions strictly providing food provisions have had insignificant impacts on childrenâs home food environment, home fruit and/or vegetable availability, and parental modelling of fruit and/or vegetable consumption. The present review suggests that, with the exception of the provision of school snacks or meals, changes to the physical environment and their effect on outcomes of interest, like dietary intake and anthropometry, were limited in the published literature. Only 8 interventions explicitly mentioned implementing some form of an environmental change other than food provisions. This included improving existing infrastructure and equipment or constructing new infrastructure, such as school gardens. Other changes involved introducing school-wide bans of high-fat and high-sugar foods and restricting the sale of foods in vending machines and canteens to healthier snack and beverage options. However, the majority of these interventions and programs were implemented in conjunction with behavioral changes, such as nutrition education, whereas only 2 interventions altered the food environment alone. Interestingly, all the studies that altered the food environment indicated some improvement, either significant or insignificant, to overall nutritious food preferences, fruit and vegetable intake, fat and fiber intake, non-SSB intake, and anthropometric measures, such as obesity, waist circumference, body fat percentage, and BMI, when compared with baseline or groups who were not exposed to environmental changes. DISCUSS: Similar to Colley et al, the majority of studies in this review used multicomponent interventions, consisting of both a behavioral component (eg, a nutrition education program) and an environmental component, defined as any policy or physical change to the environment (including infrastructure and resources). None of the studies disaggregated outcome data on the basis of the discrete behavioral and environmental components, limiting the ability to analyze and understand the environment-specific effects on nutrition outcomes in this age group. Single-component interventions mostly implemented behavioral components, such as nutritional education, that were incorporated into existing curriculum or peer-, family-, and/or community support. Notable high-quality evidence was identified in Ontario and Quebec, where changes to the curriculum resulted in improved fruit and vegetable intake by kindergarten and grade 5â6 participants. In comparison, notable high-quality evidence of multicomponent interventions mostly was found in western Canada, where studentâs dietary intake and BMI improved significantly after the implementation of nutrition education, food provisions, physical activity, and community-based initiatives in Alberta and British Columbia. DISCUSS: Social environment DISCUSS: Although schools varied in terms of their school food and nutrition initiatives and infrastructure, key barriers to the participation, acceptance, and sustainability of interventions, programs, and policies were attributed to social factors. The most common barrier was staff capacity, which led to inconsistencies in implementation and added stress on staff. Logistical challenges also prevented the availability, sourcing, and delivery of resources due to natural causes, financial constraints, and the loss of leadership and support. DISCUSS: Although meaningfully intended, school food and NPs that are specifically geared toward students in need can contribute to stigma and social exclusion of students and families experiencing food insecurity or those of lower SES when it is made obvious who is receiving meals. This may influence participation and momentum. Needs-based programs in which students and families must identify that they are food insecure or have lower SES may be counterproductive because those in need may be too shy, embarrassed, or proud to sign up. Although this finding may suggest that a universal program, instead of a needs-based one, would increase uptake, evidence in the literature suggests this may not always be guaranteed. Godin et al reported a 16% student participation rate despite offering universal breakfast programs in Ontario and Alberta. Muthuswamy et al also showed that perception is a strong factor that can significantly influence participation among students. Some fears of stigma include fear of being labeled, judged, or laughed at; teased for using meal programs; or standing out among their peers of higher SES or those with greater food security. Some of this stigmatization could also be resolved with better communication between the school or programs and students and their families. Miscommunication or a lack of communication between parents/guardians and the school about the purpose of the programs, what the programs offer, and how they work led to decreased participation rate. This is a common theme reported in the literature. DISCUSS: It is also important to consider how culture and ethnicity affect food choice and participation in these programs. Misalignment between nutrition recommendations and cultural preferences of participants and their parents can affect participation. This is seen in both Indigenous and non-Indigenous groups. This is similar to other evidence in both Canada and the United States showing that cultural appropriateness of food and cultural practices of students and their families can affect participation, regardless of need. Muthuswamy et al and Skinner et al recommend involving student input on food preferences and options in school cafeterias and meal or snack programs to improve acceptance and participation. DISCUSS: On the other hand, a key element that helped program sustainability and policy implementation was community engagement and establishing strong relationships with the community. These relationships and networks served as a resource for valuable input and voluntary support. This was especially common among the Indigenous-specific studies included, which noted key factors for successful program implementation were the involvement of Indigenous Elders and Knowledge Keepers, and building relationships and communication between stakeholder groups throughout the design and implementation phases. In alignment with the aforementioned barriers, successful implementation was also found in programs that had adequate access to resources, funding, and consistent leadership. DISCUSS: Key takeaways DISCUSS: The first key takeaway from this review is that program evaluation is inconsistent and challenging across the country. Not only is existing research and evaluation of programs and policies disproportionate across the provinces and territories, they are also largely concentrated in certain areas, such British Columbia, Ontario, and Alberta, with limited research conducted in the Territories and among Indigenous student populations. Important to note, however, is that the evidence base is rapidly evolving. A 2021 analysis of school food programs in Canada highlighted that 100% of schools in the Northwest Territories and Nunavut and 94% of schools in Yukon have school food programs, with an 87% student participation rate. However, these programs, along with other community-based programming and initiatives, are not rigorously evaluated or documented, especially in Indigenous communities, and as such, may have been absent in our literature search. This may lead to gaps in research and records reviewing these programs and their effects, and a lack of generalizability of program evaluations, given limited comprehensive representation of the student populations across the country. DISCUSS: The second key takeaway is that given the lack of federal-level policy or legislation that outlines standards and procedures, local and individualized development of programs and policies reflects immense heterogeneity in demographics, geography, and scale (ie, local or provincial/territorial), which contributes to differences in design, methodology, and implementation. These include infrastructural indicators (eg, presence of lunch programs, types of food and beverages offered in school cafeterias); KAP of school administration, teaching staff, and students; anthropometry; dietary intake; physical activity; health practices; educational gains; and academic performance. Some programs chose one or all of these measures in their design and evaluations. Given the different student populations by province or territory, cultural and ethnic groups, and urban and rural settings, it is expected that programs differ by design and implementation to best address the needs and community reflected in particular settings. Programs may also differ in their duration, which adds further complexity to the ability to evaluate effectiveness. For example, even when schools adopted the HPS framework in the design phase, the selection of core HPS components to be included were not necessarily standardized or uniformly implemented, with each school interpreting and contextualizing the framework to fit their needs and criteria. This makes it difficult to compare and contrast programs, even those under the same framework, because current programs are often administered voluntarily and operated at the discretion of individual school capacities. DISCUSS: The third key takeaway is that this review highlights the strong dependency of current research on latent construct indicators such as KAP, with few using observable biophysical indicators, such as micronutrient deficiencies and anthropometry. The most commonly reported effectiveness outcomes were dietary intake and KAP measured through quantitative surveys or qualitative interviews, which, in both cases, relied on self-reporting. Although KAP can capture key information about student acquisition of knowledge or changes in attitudes and perspectives after an educational-based intervention, there are limitations to its use. First, KAP surveys can be difficult to interpret without a benchmark or standard reference to classify KAP among the study participants. This standard reference might be achieved by comparison with a similar KAP survey conducted in a similar population with similar methods; however, realistically, this is not always possible, especially among the variable school food programs and policies that are evaluated across the country. In addition, we found in through review that health knowledge did not necessarily translate into sustained behavior changes. Significant improvements in student knowledge among participants exposed to health literacy programming concerning Canadaâs food guidelines did not translate into significant changes in food behaviors, such as vegetable intake. Even when positive food behavior changes were identified immediately after assessment, these short-term impacts were often short-lived after follow-up assessments, ranging from 2âmonths to 7âyears, showed insignificant changes in programs across the country. Most importantly, healthy eating is a much more complicated concept beyond acquiring adequate literacy to guide individual decision-making. Conducting holistic and intersectional investigations should require careful examinations of obesogenic environments, geographic location, family income, and other ecological determinants. DISCUSS: Strengths and limitations DISCUSS: Overall, this review is strengthened by the breadth and depth of the literature examined using systematic methods and evolving evidence that corroborates our findings. The wide heterogeneity and low quality of experimental study designs (ie, single or multicomponent interventions, duration, randomization, outcomes assessed) did not allow for a formal meta-analysis. Given this, all relevant studies, regardless of quality and RoB, were included in this narrative review. As well, physical activityâfocused programs and policies that did not have an explicit food and nutrition component were not included in this review. This may have excluded studies and evaluations that may have had an indirect impact on childrenâs overall nutrition and dietary behaviors. Measurement tools used in observational study designs were also highly variable and often study-specific. High-quality measurement methods are required to conduct assessments and evaluations of the school food environment to not only offer comparable data but also to better inform future policies and practices that can lead to improved diets and nutritional status. CONCL: CONCLUSION CONCL: Canada remains the only Group of Seven country without a national school meal program, with 1 in every 20 students in Canada missing lunch on a given school day. In 2021, Canadaâs federal government committed to developing a national school food policy. However, beyond this, multidisciplinary and concerted efforts across the provinces and territories at both the local and provincial/territorial levels are needed to address the multiple threats to food and nutrition security our children and adolescents face. CONCL: We found that the Canadian school-based food environment literature remains largely heterogeneous and is primarily focused on nutrition education and physical activity programs that use self-reported data that are measured through quantitative and or qualitative methods to infer changes in childrenâs nutrition. A minority of literature evaluates programs and policies connected with equity-seeking groups, despite these populations being closely associated with food insecurity. Few evaluated no-cost food provision programs, which could be owing to researcher preference or that, unfortunately, only 5% of students in Canada are covered by a school food program. This is a key area that the incoming national school food policy and future research and evaluations must address. The recent COVID-19 pandemic and current increasing inflation and food costs have exposed and possibly exacerbated already existing inequities in food systems and food environments. Even prior to the pandemic, the evidence was clear that Indigenous communities and marginalized and racialized populations are especially vulnerable to food insecurity and are unable to meet the recommendations of Canadaâs food guidelines. CONCL: Schools are a critical entry point to shaping nutrition-promoting behaviors, and this review provides much-needed evidence on school food and nutrition interventions, programs, and policies in Canada. We report in this review rich evidence on key facilitators and barriers to implementation and sustainability of programs provided by stakeholders, while also uncovering important evidence gaps that require careful examination for future evaluations. National, provincial, and local governments should design multisectoral policies and programs with equity in mind to ensure vulnerable and marginalized groups can access or achieve a sufficient, diverse, nutritious diet that is culturally appropriate and aligns with Canada's food guidelines and jurisdictional nutrition standards. Importantly, in consultation with local communities, programs must be tailored to context and cuisine to ensure maximal acceptance and engagement. full_text_sections.Title: Promoting healthy school food environments and nutrition in Canada: a systematic review of interventions, policies, and programs
full_text_sections.Abstract: Abstract Context The school food environment is a critical interface for child and adolescent nutrition, and there is a need to understand existing literature on Canadian school food environments to identify equity gaps and opportunities, and empower decision-makers to plan for future action. Objective Literature on Canadian school food and nutrition interventions, policies, programs, and their effects on diets and nutritional status are synthesized and appraised in this systematic review. Data Sources A search strategy was developed for each database used (Medline, Embase, PsycINFO, ERIC, Cochrane Collaboration, Canadian Electronic Library, BiblioMap), with a combination of free text and controlled vocabulary, for articles published from 1990 to 2021. Unpublished data and grey literature were also searched. Data Extraction Quantitative and qualitative studies with an observational or intervention study design, reviews, or program evaluations conducted in Canadian schools with participants aged 5â19.9âyears were included. Key study characteristics and risk of bias were extracted independently by 2 investigators using a standardized tool. Data Analysis A total of 298 articles were included (nâ=â192 peer reviewed and 106 from the grey literature), which were mostly conducted in Ontario (nâ=â52), British Columbia (nâ=â43), and Nova Scotia (nâ=â28). Twenty-four interventions, 5 nonevaluated programs, and 1 policy involved Indigenous populations. Overall, 86 articles measured and reported on effectiveness outcomes, including dietary intake; anthropometry; knowledge, attitudes, and practices; and physical activity. The literature remains largely heterogenous and primarily focused on nutrition education programs that use subjective assessments to infer changes in nutrition. A key facilitator to implementation and sustainability was community engagement, whereas key barriers were staff capacity, access to resources and funding, and consistent leadership. Conclusions This review provides insight into Canadian school food and nutrition interventions, programs, and policies and uncovers important evidence gaps that require careful examination for future evaluations. Governments must create supportive environments that optimize nutrition for children and adolescents through equitable policies and programs. Systematic Review Registration PROSPERO registration no. CRD42022303255.
full_text_sections.INTRO: INTRODUCTION With 6 years remaining to end hunger, food insecurity and all forms of malnutrition (United Nationsâ Sustainable Development Goal 2), global progress has regressed. Importantly, the greatest burden of malnutrition is shouldered by children and adolescents from the poorest and most marginalized communities, due to suboptimal food environments and diets. Like other high-income countries, food environments in Canada do not support the consumption of accessible, affordable, sustainable, nutritious, and healthy food. In fact, the majority of Canadian children and adolescents do not meet national dietary guidelines, and diet quality is poor. In addition, at least 1.4 million Canadian children experience food insecurity, and childhood obesity rates have doubled over the past 40âyears. With the recognition that early-life nutrition has life-long health and social implications, there have been global efforts to redesign, promote, and integrate multisectoral interventions across the life course and the continuum of care. The integration of nutrition within health, education, and social protection delivery platforms has been recognized as a critical opportunity to realize child and adolescent human rights to food and nutrition security. Schools are considered innovative platforms for life course interventions, especially for optimizing nutrition. Launched in the 1980s, the âHealth Promoting Schoolâ (HPS) approach (or âwhole-school approachâ) was developed by the World Health Organization. The approach focuses on a broad spectrum of policies, program activities, and services that contribute to the health, safety, and well-being of students, staff, and families, while assuring a supportive and enabling environment that nurtures academic growth and development. The concept of health promotion in schools has been adopted at different scales with varying approaches, such as the Comprehensive School Health Program in Canada, which comprises 8 components that relate to the following broader political, physical, and social contexts: health education, school-based health services, the school environment, physical education, food services, student counselling, staff health promotion, and community integration. A key aspect is improving the school food environment, which refers to the spaces and conditions inside and around school premises where food and beverages are available, obtained, purchased, and/or consumed, with consideration of nutritional content, promotion, pricing, and food safety. Although there are limited data on what interventions, policies, and programs can effectively improve school food environments and, ultimately, the nutrition of children and adolescents in Canada, evidence from recent systematic reviews suggests that school-based nutrition interventions can have a positive effect on dietary outcomes, including fruit and vegetables intake. However, these effects are not necessarily actualized in changes to anthropometric outcomes, like body mass index (BMI). As such, our aim in conducting this systematic review was to synthesize and appraise literature on the Canadian school food environment and nutrition interventions, policies, and programs, and their effects on diets and nutritional status, while identifying research gaps, particularly for equity-seeking populations, and opportunities to empower decision-makers to plan for future action.
full_text_sections.METHODS: METHODS Our search was conducted on December 20, 2021, for publications from the year 1990 to the present without language restrictions or search filters (ie, by population or outcome) within the following databases: MEDLINE, Embase, PsycINFO, ERIC, Cochrane Collaboration, the Canadian Electronic Library (ie, Canadian Public Policy Collection, and the Canadian Electronic Library), Canadian Health Research Collection, and BiblioMap (the EPPI-Centre database of health promotion research) (see TableâS1 in the Supporting Information online). Search strategies were developed for each database along with free text and controlled vocabulary (ie, Medical Subject Heading terms). Additional search terms were included in consultation with an information specialist. Key search terms included the following: school health services, school nutrition, health promotion, and school policies. Our protocol was registered with PROSPERO (no. CRD42022303255). A search for unpublished data and grey literature that met eligibility criteria was conducted. Some of the electronic databases we searched include a combination of published and unpublished studies. To ensure maximum coverage of unpublished literature and reduce the potential for publication bias, organizational websites and databases were searched using a keyword search in the area of food security and nutrition (see TableâS2 in the Supporting Information online). Where possible, we consulted technical experts regarding unpublished data discussed in webinars, newsletters, and other media sources. Reference lists of relevant systematic reviews, commentaries, and editorials were hand searched to find other eligible studies. We included quantitative and qualitative studies conducted in Canada that had an observational study design (ie, cross-sectional, cohort, case-control, and ecological studies), interventional study design (ie, randomized controlled trials [RCTs], quasi-experimental studies [QES], intermittent time series, and controlled before-after studies), reviews (ie, systematic, literature, and scoping), or program evaluations. We included participants aged 5â19.9âyears (preschool, primary, middle, or high school). Studies that included participants outside of this age range and did not report disaggregated data were excluded (Tableâ1). We evaluated included studies based on the RE-AIM (Reach, Effectiveness, Adoption, Implementation, and Maintenance) framework that were focused on intervention, nonevaluated programs, or policy implementation. Importantly, adoption relates to the absolute number, proportion, and representativeness of interventions, nonevaluated programs, and policies adopted within provinces or territories. Reach relates to the absolute number, proportion, and representativeness of schools or individuals who participate in a given intervention or nonevaluated program or are affected by a policy. Implementation refers to the fidelity to various elements of an intervention, nonevaluated program, or policy, including consistency of delivery as intended. Importantly, it also includes adaptations made to interventions and implementation strategies. For the purposes of this study, key elements were changes to the school food environment, including food accessibility, food availability, and food promotion, as well as implementation barriers and facilitators. Maintenance refers to the long-term effects (â¥6âmonths) of an intervention, policy, or nonevaluated program on outcomes after it is completed either at the setting (institutionalization) or individual (retention of effectiveness) level. Effectiveness relates to the impact of an intervention, nonevaluated program, or policy on important individual outcomes, including potential negative effects, and variability across subgroups (generalizability or heterogeneity of effects). In this review, we considered the following outcomes, which were author defined, under effectiveness on individuals: direct measures of consumption (ie, frequency of consumption, energy intake, macronutrient and micronutrient intake, food group intake, food consumption score, portion size); direct measures of diet quality (ie, food security, diet diversity score, meal score, Healthy Eating Index, other diet quality indices, diet adequacy); diet-related biomarkers (ie, micronutrient deficiencies); anthropometry (ie, nutritional status); physical activity; and education (ie, changes to knowledge, attitudes, and practices [KAP]). We considered any interventions, nonevaluated programs, policies, regulations, and guidelines that affected the political, social, and physical school food and nutrition environment, including interventions for food availability, accessibility, policy, pricing, and promotion. For example, we included studies related to the provision of foods, including meals (breakfast, lunch, or dinner) or snacks consumed at school (hereafter, in-school feeding), and foods distributed to the family and consumed outside of the school setting (hereafter, take-home ration). We also included studies examining the economic (ie, price of healthy and unhealthy food items recorded, childrenâs spending restriction) and sociocultural (ie, behavioral interventions such as food and nutrition education) school environments. There was no minimum duration of follow-up for inclusion. Studies conducted in schools were eligible for inclusion. Studies and reports that used data from multiple countries, including Canada, were required to report disaggregated data by country to be included in this review. Our primary outcomes were used as eligibility criteria for including studies (ie, if a study did not report any of the primary outcomes, it was excluded). However, we did not exclude studies on the basis of how that outcome was reported (ie, that an effect size is not estimable although the outcome was clearly measured). We excluded animal studies, conference abstracts, and letters or comments. Data collection We assessed study eligibility starting with title and abstract screening of all unique records identified by our search strategy. Once duplicates were removed, all records were uploaded into Covidence (Melbourne, VIC, Australia). Title and abstract screening was conducted by 3 independent reviewers (B.C., E.K., G.D.). Records were assessed according to the following exclusion criteria: incorrect topic area, ineligible document type, and duplicate document. Full article text was found for all eligible studies and uploaded into Covidence. These were screened by 2 reviewers (G.D., E.K.) using the following exclusion criteria: incorrect topic area, incorrect population, ineligible document type, duplicate document, or no primary outcomes. Disagreements between the 2 reviewers were resolved by a third independent reviewer (B.C.). Data from all eligible texts that proceeded to full-text extraction were extracted by 2 reviewers according to the following domains: general information, study setting and population, primary outcomes, and secondary outcomes. Because we expected variability in reported age bands, we made a post hoc decision in analysis of results at different age bands. Extracted data were matched by 2 independent reviewers (E.K., G.D., C.O., or R.J.), with any conflicts resolved by a third reviewer (B.C.). We attempted to contact authors of the original reports to obtain further details if required. Risk of bias Given the various study designs, we assessed the risk of bias (RoB) through different tools: for observational studies, the National Institutes of Health Quality Assessment Tool for Cohort and Cross-sectional Studies was used; for intervention studies, the Cochraneâs Risk of Bias Tool; for nonrandomized controlled trials, we used Risk of Bias in Nonrandomized Studies of Interventions tool; and for systematic reviews, A Measurement Tool to Assess Systematic Reviews was used. Studies were scored by 2 independent review authors (E.K., G.D.). Each study was assigned an overall quality score, classified as low, low-moderate, moderate, moderate-serious, and serious. Scores from the 2 independent reviewers (E.K., G.D.) were compared and a final score was determined. In case of disagreements, a third review author (B.C.) was consulted. Data synthesis We forecasted that a meta-analysis would not be possible because of the scope of the study research questions and the range of outcome measures and methods. We narratively synthesized the findings that emerged. Results were summarized first on the basis of geography (ie, by province or territory) and then by study design (ie, RCT, QES, or observational), RoB assessment and impact on primary and secondary outcomes. For each extracted outcome, we analyzed the association on the basis of its effect estimate (odds ratio [OR] or risk ratio [RR]), confidence interval (CI), and whether the finding was statistically significant (Pââ¤â0.05). Additionally, results were contextualized on the basis of social stratification (ie, by age, sex, socioeconomic status, geography, and ethnicity), using the Nutrition Equity Framework as guidance, as well as the broader political, physical, and social contexts that are key elements in the World Health Organization HPS.
